Award.AwardTitle: Comparative Genomics of a Species Radiation: Sequencing the Apple Tribe
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Sarah Mathews (Harvard University)

Key Collaborator: Erin MacNeal Rehrig (Fitchburg State University)

Species radiations are a striking feature of evolution and may be responsible for much of life's diversity. Yet understanding the evolution of species radiations and how genome evolution progresses in this context remains a central problem in biology. Members of the rose family (Rosaceae) include familiar domesticates such as roses, apples, peaches, almonds, strawberries, and cherries. An intriguing and important radiation within Rosaceae produced the apple, pear, and quince genera, along with several valuable ornamentals. These are members of a clade of about 750 woody species distributed in 35 genera with a base chromosome number of x = 17 (tribe Maleae). The sister group of this clade is the genus Gillenia, which has just two species, both herbaceous perennials with a base chromosome number of x = 9. The Maleae are particularly attractive for the study of genome evolution in the context of a species radiation because of their generally small genome sizes and monophyletic roots in a single whole genome duplication (WGD) that postdates their divergence from Gillenia. Early diverging Maleae are similar to Gillenia in having dry fruits and few species. But after the evolution of the pome, the fleshy fruit found in most Maleae and the basis for their economic importance, they diversified into 32 genera, sorting into lineages with distinctive phenotypic, life history, and ecological traits, including lineages in which repeated hybridization and polyploidy events have contributed to their species-richness. This project will test the hypothesis that the infusion of a vast numbers of duplicate genes via WGD provided evolutionary potential for the radiating Maleae. The specific aims are to: (1) generate genome sequence from a small number of diploid genomes (both pre- and post-WGD) and determine the extent to which genic regions can be assembled and the history of duplicated genes reconstructed in selected Maleae genera; and, (2) establish the best sequencing and assembly approaches for the genome scan of a diploid/tetraploid species pair in Maleae. If successful, the project will provide resources for advancing our understanding of the evolution of economically and ecologically important processes such as fruit development, volatile production, changes in climate tolerance, and resistance to pests through the generation of thousands of new markers for breeding programs as well as genome sequences from two closely related species of Malus that differ with respect to ploidy.

This project will provide research training for a postdoctoral fellow and a faculty member from Fitchburg State University, a primarily undergraduate institution in Massachusetts. All sequence data will be deposited and accessible through GenBank and the Genome Database for Rosaceae (GDR; www.rosaceae.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Comparative Genomics of a Species Radiation: Sequencing the Apple Tribe

NSF EAGER award IOS-1416825

PI: Sarah Mathews; Co-PI: Levi Yant; Postdoctoral Fellow: Jeffrey DaCosta; Collaborator: Erin Rehrig

 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

Rapid radiations of species occur when a single lineage successively splits into many lineages in a relatively short period of geological time. They are a striking feature in the evolution of life on earth, and make a significant contribution to increasing biodiversity. We currently don’t have a good explanation of why rapid radiations occur in some lineages but not in others.

One such radiation occurred in the rose family, generating the apple clade, or Tribe Maleae. Maleae include the apple, pear, quince, loquat, hawthorn, rowan, cotoneaster, firethorn, service berry, and Japanese quince genera. Maleae originated after an ancient whole genome duplication (a process in which the chromosome number is doubled) that occurred between 44 and 65 million years ago. Prior to the origin of the pome (the technical term for fruits such as apples, pears, and quinces), two lineages with dry fruits evolved, which together comprise just seven species. Following the evolution of the pome, Maleae diversified into about 30 genera with more than 700 species. In many of these genera, including in the apple and pear genera, more recent whole genome duplications have occurred.

We are using Maleae as a system to 1) study the role of genome duplication and the evolution of gene families in generating diversity in woody plants, and 2) investigate genome differentiation in diploid (with 2 sets of chromosomes) versus tetraploid (with 4 sets of chromosomes) crabapple populations that originated after a recent genome duplication in the Malus coronaria species complex. The one-year EAGER award allowed us to sequence the genomes of a subset of the Maleae highlighted in Figure 1 and to demonstrate the feasibility of our sequencing, assembly, annotation, and analytical approaches.

We have shown that draft genome sequences in Maleae can be generated for about $2,500 per genome, and that our draft assemblies are sufficient for the 1) reconstruction of fates of duplicate genes following genome duplication, that is, whether duplicates are lost or retained through speciation events following the genome duplication, 2) detection of significant episodes of gene family evolution (significant expansion or contraction of gene family size) in Maleae, and of the functional nature of the gene families involved, and 3) detection of selective sweeps during the differentiation of diploid and tetraploid populations in the Malus coronaria complex. The data are allowing us to 1) discover whether specific patterns of gene loss or retention after ancient whole genome duplications contribute to speciation, 2) associate expansions and contractions in gene families with plant phenotypes, and 3) identify genes that might contribute to the maintenance of genome stability following whole genome duplication.

 

BROADER IMPACTS

We used Maleae as a study system to develop an undergraduate laboratory module to teach phylogenetics and character evolution. This lab was implemented in a botany course at Fitchburg State University in the Fall of 2015.
